Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: An angry client is loudly criticising a cut moments before the salon is due to close.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: A fellow activist is live-streaming from a small demonstration right now and has asked for more people to show up if they are free.
Story: The clock on the salon wall ticks closer to closing time as my client’s voice rises, echoing off the mirrors. She’s furious about her haircut, gesturing wildly, demanding a fix. I try to keep my tone calm, apologizing, offering to adjust the style, but she’s not having it. My coworkers are already sweeping up, glancing at me with sympathy. My phone buzzes in my pocket—a message from Maya, my friend and fellow activist. She’s live-streaming from the square, her text urgent: “We need more people here, can you come?” I glance at the screen, seeing the small crowd, the signs, the cause I care so much about. But here, in the salon, I’m expected to be the patient professional, smoothing over complaints, making sure every client leaves happy. My heart pounds as I weigh the angry client in front of me against the call to action from my activist friends. I feel pulled in two directions, the pressure mounting, unsure which role I’m supposed to honor in this moment.
